content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Gitelman syndrome (<math alttext="G S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is a heritable disorder caused by a mutation in the <math alttext="S L C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SLC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene that encodes a <math alttext="N a with a plus one charge / C l with a minus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> cotransporter protein (<math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1) that is expressed in kidney cells. When molecules or ions are moved by cotransporters, the molecules or ions must move across a membrane together, either in the same direction or in opposite directions. The <math alttext="N a with a plus one charge / C l with a minus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> cotransporter simultaneously transports <math alttext="N a with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C l with a minus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> from one region of the kidney (Region <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) into the cell. Other transporters in kidney cell membranes include the <math alttext="N a with a plus one charge / K with a plus one charge A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1) and a <math alttext="N a with a plus one charge / C a with a plus two charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> cotransporter (<math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1) that allow ions to move across the membrane between the kidney cell and a second region of the kidney (Region <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). Kidney cells also have channel proteins like the <math alttext="C a with a plus two charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> channel (<math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1) that transports <math alttext="C a with a plus two charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> from Region <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into the kidney cell. A model representing the exchange of various ions between the kidney cell and the two extracellular regions is shown in Figure 1. The size of an ion's symbol indicates the relative concentration of that ion in a given area. The larger symbol indicates the area of higher concentration, and the smaller symbol indicates the area of lower concentration. Figure 1. Model representing the exchange of ions between a kidney cell and two isolated extracellular regions. The larger symbols indicate the areas of higher ion concentration, and the smaller symbols indicate the areas of lower ion concentration. Researchers have determined that there are a number of mutations to the <math alttext="S L C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SLC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> wild-type allele (<math alttext="S L C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SLC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) that result in <math alttext="G S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. One mutant allele, <math alttext="S L C g s 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SLC-gs1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, results from a single nucleotide deletion that creates a stop codon midway through the coding region of the gene. A second mutant allele, <math alttext="S L C g s 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SLC-gs2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, results from a mutation that disrupts the sequence of a splicing site between an intron and an exon, preventing the removal of an intron. To better understand how <math alttext="G S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is inherited, researchers studied a number of families with a history of <math alttext="G S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The pedigree of one of these families is shown in Figure 2. Figure 2. Pedigree of a family with a history of <math alttext="G S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> caused by two different mutant alleles (a) Describe the characteristics of the cotransporter labeled <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1 that allow it to be embedded among phospholipids like those in the membrane between Region <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the kidney cell.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Gitelman syndrome (<math alttext="G S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is a heritable disorder caused by a mutation in the <math alttext="S L C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SLC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene that encodes a <math alttext="N a with a plus one charge / C l with a minus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> cotransporter protein (<math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1) that is expressed in kidney cells. When molecules or ions are moved by cotransporters, the molecules or ions must move across a membrane together, either in the same direction or in opposite directions. Other transporters in kidney cell membranes include the <math alttext="N a with a plus one charge / K with a plus one charge A T P ase" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>ATPase</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1) and a <math alttext="N a with a plus one charge / C a with a plus two charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> cotransporter (<math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1) that allow ions to move across the membrane between the kidney cell and a second region of the kidney (Region <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). Kidney cells also have channel proteins like the <math alttext="C a with a plus two charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> channel (<math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1) that transports <math alttext="C a with a plus two charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> from Region <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into the kidney cell. A model representing the exchange of various ions between the kidney cell and the two extracellular regions is shown in Figure 1. The size of an ion's symbol indicates the relative concentration of that ion in a given area. The larger symbol indicates the area of higher concentration, and the smaller symbol indicates the area of lower concentration. Figure 1. Model representing the exchange of ions between a kidney cell and two isolated extracellular regions. The larger symbols indicate the areas of higher ion concentration, and the smaller symbols indicate the areas of lower ion concentration. Researchers have determined that there are a number of mutations to the <math alttext="S L C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SLC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> wild-type allele (<math alttext="S L C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SLC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) that result in <math alttext="G S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. One mutant allele, <math alttext="S L C g s 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SLC-gs1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, results from a single nucleotide deletion that creates a stop codon midway through the coding region of the gene. A second mutant allele, <math alttext="S L C g s 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SLC-gs2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, results from a mutation that disrupts the sequence of a splicing site between an intron and an exon, preventing the removal of an intron. To better understand how <math alttext="G S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is inherited, researchers studied a number of families with a history of <math alttext="G S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The pedigree of one of these families is shown in Figure 2. Figure 2. Pedigree of a family with a history of <math alttext="G S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> caused by two different mutant alleles (a) Describe the characteristics of the cotransporter labeled <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1 that allow it to be embedded among phospholipids like those in the membrane between Region <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the kidney cell.

(b) Explain the effect of the mutation in the <math alttext="S L C g s 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SLC-gs1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> allele on the transport protein encoded by the gene. Explain why the transporter labeled <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1 does not require <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to move ions between Region <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the kidney cells.

(c) Predict the immediate effect on the movement of <math alttext="N a with a plus one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> into the cell from Region <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> if a mutation results in a nonfunctional <math alttext="C a with a plus two charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> channel (<math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 1). Based on Figure 1, provide reasoning to justify your prediction.

(d) Individual <math alttext="1 in the third generation" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in Figure 2 has the <math alttext="G S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> phenotype, while individual <math alttext=" 2 in the third generation" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III-2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> does not. Predict the probability that another sibling of individuals <math alttext="1 in the third generation" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2 in the third generation" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III-2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will also have <math alttext="G S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
